hedline.hl1: Court Rejects Appeal Of Eccentric Crime Boss

abstract.p: Vincent Gigante, who once wandered streets of Greenwich Village in pajamas and bathrobe in what government said was silly attempt to show that he was mentally incompetent to stand trial for his mob-related crimes, loses his final appeal when US Supreme Court refuses to hear his case (S)

block.p: Vincent Gigante, who once wandered the streets of Greenwich Village in pajamas and bathrobe in what the government said was a silly attempt to show that he was mentally incompetent to stand trial for his mob-related crimes, lost his final appeal yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his case.
So Mr. Gigante, now in his early 70's, will continue to serve a 12-year prison sentence for racketeering and murder-conspiracy convictions.

Vincent Gigante, who once wandered the streets of Greenwich Village in pajamas and bathrobe in what the government said was a silly attempt to show that he was mentally incompetent to stand trial for his mob-related crimes, lost his final appeal yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his case.
So Mr. Gigante, now in his early 70's, will continue to serve a 12-year prison sentence for racketeering and murder-conspiracy convictions.

Mr. Gigante's lawyers had asserted that the testimony of a witness from a remote location on closed-circuit television had violated Mr. Gigante's constitutional right to face his accusers. A federal appeals court disagreed.
